title: People and Communities in Western Sydney
text:
In this document, we will take you through the demographic, socioeconomic, and health profiles of communities in Western Sydney from 2011 to 2021.



Data Sources


The analysis is based on Census data from 2011 and 2021, accessed through the Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) TableBuilder.





Acknowledgement

We acknowledge the Traditional Custodians of the lands on which the communities of WSLHD live, gather, and work.

We pay our deepest respects to Elders past and present, who have cared for this Country for countless generations and continue to uphold cultural knowledge, identity, and connection to land.

We also extend this respect to all Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples who engage with this work, and recognise their enduring contributions to community health, wellbeing, and cultural heritage.






 Image Source: WSLHD Media








Welcome to Sydney, Australia!




This is a city map.




The blue marker represents the iconic Sydney Opera House, an enduring symbol of Sydney that attracts visitors from all over the world.






From the Sydney Opera House, about 30 kilometres to the west, lies Western Sydney, a region rising rapidly. 




The red marker represents Parramatta CBD, which is the vibrant heart of Western Sydney. 




Next, we will tell you a story about Western Sydney and its people.


















Let’s begin with a brief introduction to Western Sydney.




This is a partial map of New South Wales.




Let’s turn our attention to the areas outlined in purple. They represent the 6 NSW Metropolitan Local Health Districts:

Nepean Blue Mountains
Northern Sydney
South Eastern Sydney
South Western Sydney
Sydney
Western Sydney





These 6 LHDs form the healthcare network of metropolitan NSW, providing health services to the people living in this region.




The orange area represents WSLHD, recognised as a leader in clinical care, research, and education across Western Sydney.




Let’s take a closer look at the population shifts in metropolitan NSW from 2011 to 2021.





















According to 2011 Census, around 4.14 million people lived in the metropolitan region, accounting for about 60% of the entire NSW population.




By 2021, that metropolitan population had grown to almost 5 million, accounting for more than 60% of the entire NSW population.




Western Sydney and South Western Sydney alone each passed the milestone of 1 million residents.




Western Sydney’s population growth rate alone has reached closely 30%. 




Next, let’s break down the metropolitan region in more detail.




Each Local Health District can be mapped using Statistical Area Level 2 (SA2) boundaries.

Defined by the ABS, an SA2 represents a community where people live, work, and interact socially and economically.


While SA2s do not always fit neatly within a single LHD, together they provide a useful way to examine communities at a smaller geographic scale.





We calculated population growth rates by SA2. From this, we discovered that…




We identified high-grwoth SA2s with growth rate exceeding 100%.




Also, we found that most of high-grwoth SA2s are concentrated in Western Sydney. 




Next, we focus on the high-grwoth SA2s within Western Sydney. 




Back in 2011, their populations were all under 10,000. Over just ten years, these communities grew at an extraordinary pace.


This rapid change signals that WSLHD is full of fascinating and valuable patterns for us to explore…























































Now, let’s break down WSLHD.




WSLHD is responsible for delivering public healthcare across 4 local government areas (LGAs):


Blacktown
The Hills Shire
Parramatta
Cumberland





This is Blacktown.

Blacktown is the largest LGA in WSLHD by population, and the fastest-growing one as well.
In just a decade, its population jumped from over 300K to more than 400K, marking an impressive growth rate of over 30%.






This is The Hills Shire.

The Hills Shire is the largest LGA in WSLHD by land size, and the one that grew the fastest between 2011 and 2021, with its population soaring by 33%.






This is Parramatta.

Parramatta is the CBD of Western Sydney and the second largest LGA in WSLHD by population.
Between 2011 and 2021, it rose from the third to the second most populous LGA in WSLHD, with its population surpassing 200K.






This is Cumberland.

Cumberland was formerly known as Holroyd before being renamed in 2016. Between 2011 and 2021, its population grew steadily, surpassing the 200k mark by 2021.






let’s explore how the populations of the four LGAs have grown between 2011 and 2021.






























We now integrate the population bar charts of the four LGAs for a comparative view.




But that’s not enough…




If we break the population down into four age groups:


Children & Teens (0–19)
Young Adults (20–39)
Middle-aged Adults (40–59)
Elderly People (60+)





An interesting pattern begins to emerge…




What we see is a surge of young adults flowing into Western Sydney, becoming the driving force of the region’s population.

Across all four LGAs, young adults grew by about 30%, reaching more than 350K people in total.




Alongside the growth of the young workforce, there has also been a significant increase in the number of children and teenagers, reflecting higher birth rates.

This suggests that young families represent the dominant household profile in Western Sydney.




But there’s another striking pattern…




In just ten years, the 60+ population grew by over 40% in total, the highest increase of all age groups.

In Blacktown and The Hills Shire, the growth rate even topped 50%, a clear sign of the aging people healthcare challenges already confronting WSLHD.




We’ve seen a surge of young workers flowing into Western Sydney. We believe this is strongly connected to the arrival of new migrants.




Now, let’s dive deeper into the cultural diversity.




First, we look at the country of birth distribution by metropolitan LHDs.




In 2021, 47.0% of WSLHD’s population was born overseas, the highest proportion among all metropolitan LHDs.




However, not only the country of birth.




Also, the languages speaking at home show a similar proportion.




In 2021, non-English native speakers made up more than 50% of WSLHD. 




The figures highlight Western Sydney as the most culturally diverse part of NSW metropolitan.




This pattern also makes us more interested in the migrant structure of Western Sydney, so we continue to break down WSLHD.




Across WSLHD, Cumberland and Parramatta have a majority overseas-born population (~52–53%).

Blacktown is roughly balanced (~50/50), while The Hills Shire is more Australian-born (~58%).




Home-language patterns mirror this:

Cumberland and Parramatta have a majority of Non-English (55–65%)., near parity in Blacktown, and The Hills Shire is English-dominant (~59%).




So what we really want to know:

Who are the main migrant communities in Western Sydney?




Here, we intergrate the top 10 overseas countries of birth and the top 10 non-English languages speaking at home to see how migration and language connect across WSLHD.




India leads by a large margin, with China and the Philippines next. 




Other countries like South Korea, Nepal, Lebanon, and Sri Lanka add to the rich mix of communities across Western Sydney. 




Mandarin, Arabic, Cantonese, and Hindi are leading the way. 




Punjabi, Korean, Tamil, and Tagalog are also commonly speaking at home. 




Also, we identified the SA2s where both the overseas-born population and the share of non-English languages speaking at home are higher than WSLHD’s overall averages.




These hotspots are largely clustered in Cumberland and Parramatta. 


















































































Let’s look at the healthcare network in WSLHD.




The acute care facilities within WSLHD include Blacktown Hospital, Mount Druitt Hospital, Westmead Hospital, Auburn Hospital

In addition, Cumberland Hospital serves as a specialised mental health facility.




This is Blacktown Hospital. 




This is Mount Druitt Hospital. 




They are Westmead Hospital and Cumberland Hospital 




This is Auburn Hospital. 




These hospitals, along with their dedicated healthcare workers, stand at the frontline of care, protecting the health of over a million people.















Next, we turn to see how socioeconomic factors and health outcomes interact to shape life in WSLHD.




In the 2021 Census, ten selected health conditions were surveyed.




We used these results to compare WSLHD with other metropolitan LHDs across conditions, including:


Asthma
Arthritis
Mental Health
Diabetes
Heart Disease
Cancer
Lung Condtions
kidney Disease
Dementia
Stroke





We found that asthma, arthritis, and mental health conditions had the highest prevalence across all metropolitan LHDs, each exceeding 6%.




The situation in WSLHD is also concerning, with all three conditions above 5%.




However, the prevalence of diabetes in WSLHD (5.2%) is notably higher than the metropolitan (4.5%).




Next, we will analyse how these four conditions relate to socioeconomic factors within WSLHD.




We considered key socioeconomic factors:


Education level
Occupation type
Unemployment
Income


Together with the four most prevalent health conditions:


Arthritis
Asthma
Mental health
Diabetes





By plotting these two dimensions together, we can see how health and socioeconomic disadvantage intersect across WSLHD.




The SA2s showing both high socioeconomic disadvantage and heavy health burdens are clustered in southern Blacktown. 




These high hotspots cluster in southern Blacktown. We also note a smaller set of SA2s in Cumberland showing medium health burden but high socioeconomic disadvantage—areas to watch as potential emerging risk zones.




Beyond health factors alone, the pattern may also relate to the local living environment, so we next examine housing quality.




In the distribution of social housing proportions…




we can see that areas with a high share of social housing among occupied private dwellings are concentrated in southern Blacktown, while some SA2s with moderate proportions appear in Cumberland. 




We suspect that the high concentration of social housing, where residents live under poor housing conditions, may also play a key role in shaping local health outcomes.




To explore this relationship, we next compare social housing with the health burden across WSLHD.




When combining social housing proportions with the health burden index across WSLHD.




we can find a clear pattern:

SA2s with a higher share of social housing tend to experience a higher health burden.

Most of these areas fall within the high or very high socioeconomic disadvantage categories.




This pattern highlights the strong connection between housing disadvantage and health burden in WSLHD.




Next, we highlight the SA2s that show high health burden and high socioeconomic disadvantage.




Of the 12 SA2s, 11 cluster in southern Blacktown, and one lies in Cumberland.




In the 11 SA2s located in southern Blacktown, these areas make up 51.4% of Blacktown’s total population and 18.4% of the entire WSLHD.




Next, we zoom in on southern Blacktown, where high disadvantage meets high health burden, to see how these areas perform across the four most common health conditions.




Among the 11 SA2s, nine show similar patterns, with the prevalence of the four conditions ranging between 5% and 8%.




However, Lethbridge Park – Tregear and Bidwill – Hebersham – Emerton, their rates for four conditions are above 7%, and asthma alone is nearing 11%. 




Let’s put these 11 SA2s back on the map and see where they cluster within Blacktown.













































Check out our graphic




We can keep referring to it as several triggers scroll by…




… and have OJS code elsewhere in the document to animate it












The key takeaways from Western Sydney’s journey between 2011 and 2021



  
     
      
         Population Growth

        1.04M
                         residents in 2021, +29.6% since 2011.
        
                         
        32.6%
                         of residents were young adults (20–39) in 2021.
        
        
        43.3%
                         growth of the 60+ population (2011–2021).
        
      

      
         Cultural Diversity
        ~50%
                         of residents were new immigrants in 2021.
        
                         
        India and China (excluding SARs and Taiwan)
                         were the top two overseas countries of birth.
        
        
        Cumberland and Parramatta
                         were LGAs with high concentrations of immigrants in 2021.
        
      

      
         Health Inequalities
        
        Asthma, Arthritis, Mental Health, and Diabetes
                         were the top four health conditions with the highest prevalence.
        
        
        51.4%
                         of Blacktown’s population lives in the south, forming the core of health inequality hotspots.
        
                      
        Lethbridge Park – Tregear and Bidwill – Hebersham – Emerton
                         were the top two hardest-hit areas in 2021.
        
      
    
  

  

This document was created with Quarto and closeread.


Created by Zahcary Xie
